awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Thermal Materials Discovery via Deep Learning based High-Throughput Computational Screening
awd_abstract_narration:
EAGER: Thermal Materials Discovery via Deep Learning based High-Throughput Computational Screening

Abstract:

Non-technical summary:

High-throughput computational screening of materials with target thermal conductivity has the capability to transform many industries such as thermoelectricity generation and high performance micro-/nano electronic devices, which produce a significant amount of excess heat during operation and searching for materials with high thermal conductivity is extremely important for the disruptive development of such micro-/nano-electronics in order to prolong their working life and increase reliability However, this potential has not been implemented due to the huge computational resources needed by current first-principles based thermal conductivity calculations and challenges of theoretical models because of the highly complex and nonlinear relationships from atomic structures of materials to the thermal transport properties. Deep learning has transformed an increasing number of fields where big data are available such as image and speech recognition, and medical image analysis. However, the materials science has remained largely untapped by deep learning despite its high economical potential. This two-year EAGER project aims to develop novel deep neural network techniques to achieve fast and accurate computational prediction of thermal conductivity for high-throughput thermal material discovery. The development of a reliable, fast, and accurate deep learning models is a necessity towards experimental validation and realistic application of high-throughput thermal materials screening. Simultaneously the program will aim to enhance diversity by engaging minority and underrepresented students to participate in STEM research. The participants will also develop understanding of both atomistic simulations of thermal transport and big data analytics; hence contributing to workforce development.

Technical summary:

Deep learning algorithm has been well developed in computer science, while direct thermal conductivity prediction from atomic structures has been made available in materials science. However, intuitive combination of this progress is not an easy task, since the scientific data (thermal conductivity of materials) cannot be quickly expanded to the level required by deep learning. To this end, this project will use heterogeneous multi-resolution thermal conductivity data and scarce data for training efficient and accurate deep learning models, which has never been realized for AlphaGO-like deep learning models before. In this exploratory stage, the focus will be on (1) developing graph and spatial 3D convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for thermal conductivity modeling by exploiting their automated hierarchical feature learning and non-linear mapping learning, and (2) developing multi-resolution data based deep neural network models for thermal conductivity prediction. (3) Experimental and DFT-based computational validation of predicted materials with extremely high or low thermal conductivity. A robust, reliable, and high accuracy deep learning model for thermal conductivity prediction will facilitate development of advanced functional materials in industry, such as energy conversion, storage, and thermal management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Our research focuses on two aspects of research including deep learning and machine algorithms for materials informatics and applications of computational algorithms for thermal materials discovery and mechanism understanding. First, we developed state-of-the-art graph neural network algorithms GATGNN and DeeperGATGNN for materials property prediction, which have demonstrated strong scalability. We also developed the first-of-its kind deep generative adversarial network (GAN) based materials composition generator for design of new materials, which is published in ?Nature npj computational materials?. We also developed active learning models and algorithms for efficient exploration in the huge material design space and applied it for wide-bandgap materials design. We further developed a series of new kinds of crystal structure prediction algorithms based on the concept of contact map and distance matrix prediction idea from the protein structure prediction field. We also found many crystal materials share a high similarity in terms of their crystal structures such as e.g. perovskites. We thus developed TCSP, a template based crystal structure prediction algorithm and we provide it as a web service at http://www.materialsatlas.com/crystalstructure. We also developed Inverse design algorithms for composite metal oxide optical materials based on deep transfer learning and global optimization, which demonstrates the power of combining deep learning material property prediction models with global search capability of genetic algorithms. Another key feature of new materials search is that we usually look for ?outlier? materials that are usually located in the sparse areas which makes it challenging to model by interpolation based machine learning models. To explore this issue, we develop algorithms for efficiently searching extreme mechanical properties via boundless objective-free exploration and minimal first-principles calculations, which is published in the prestigious journal npj Computational Materials. We also developed 3D convolutional neural networks models to predict elastic property based on electronic charge density, a universal representation of crystal structures. We also contribute to the material informatics community by developing algorithms and related web services for critical temperature prediction, crystal system and space group prediction, non-symmetry optical materials prediction, voltage prediction of battery electrode materials, lattice vibration frequencies, and XRD spectrum prediction, many of which are accessible at our material informatics web portal at http://www.materialsatlas.org. 

Using the advanced deep learning and machine learning models, we have applied them for exploring new thermal materials and mechanisms. In Machine Learning Accelerated Discovery of Promising Thermal Energy Storage Materials with High Heat Capacity published in ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, we trained a deeperGATGNN network model for predicting the heat capability of 32,026 structures and found 322 high heat capability materials with MnIn2Se4, which exhibits extremely high heat capacity, even higher than that of the Dulong?Petit limit at room temperature. This study paves the way for accelerating the discovery of novel thermal energy storage materials by combining machine learning with minimal DFT inquiry.  We also conducted Large scale computation of a dataset of real space electronic charge density of cubic inorganic materials from density functional theory (DFT) calculations, which can be used to model the property-charge-density relationships of diverse material properties. Using first principle DFT calculation, we also obtained novel insights into lattice thermal transport in nanocrystalline Mg3Sb2 and showed the crucial role of higher-order phonon scattering. In a paper published in Materials Advances, we conducted high-throughput computational evaluation of lattice thermal conductivity using an optimized Slack model, we proposed an optimized Slack model. As a result, the κ predicted by the optimized Slack model agrees reasonably with the κ measured in experiments, which is much better than the previous prediction. The optimized Slack model proposed in this study can be used for further high-throughput computational evaluation of κ , which would be helpful for finding materials of ultrahigh or ultralow κ with broad applications. We also showed that Electronic charge density as a fast approach for predicting Li-ion migration pathways in superionic conductors with first-principles level precision and anomalous thermal conductivity can be induced by high dispersive optical phonons in rubidium and cesium halides. Our Co-PI Dr. Ming hu further examined why thermal conductivity of CaO is lower than that of CaS, which is published in Nanotechnology. We also applied symbolic regression models for thermal conductivity prediction and showed that machine learning models for thermal conductivity have a severe issue in their generalization capability: they are good for samples with dense neighbors and very bad for predictions of outlier samples.  We also explored the mechanism underlying the exceptionally high thermal conductivity after ?alloying? two-dimensional gallium nitride (GaN) and aluminum nitride (AlN), which would bring valuable insight for the future research of materials with applications in high-performance thermal management. 

This project has enabled us to train multiple Ph.D. students and undergraduate students fostering their interests in cross-disciplinary research.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2023
Modified by: Jianjun Hu
